importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Polls open in Bolivia's presidential run-off election, marking a pivotal moment in the country's political transition.
The winner of the run-off election will take office on this date, signaling the start of a new presidential administration.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Voting hours in Bolivia during the run-off election, from 8am to 4pm local time (12:00 GMT to 20:00 GMT).

keyTakeAways: Bolivia is facing its most severe economic crisis in decades, with inflation over 20%, fuel and dollar shortages, and long queues at petrol stations.
The presidential run-off pits conservative former interim President Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga (65) against centrist economist and Senator Rodrigo Paz (58), son of former leftist President Jaime Zamora.
The Movement Towards Socialism (MAS) party, which has ruled Bolivia since 2006, failed to field a candidate in the run-off and is effectively ending its dominance.

Both candidates promise economic reform, including reducing universal fuel subsidies, but propose different approaches: Quiroga favors radical market liberalization and privatization; Paz supports a more gradual, inclusive model of capitalism.
The election marks a shift away from decades of socialist rule and toward market-friendly policies aligned with the United States, signaling a potential realignment in Bolivia’s foreign policy.
US Secretary of State Marco Rubio described the election as a 'transformative opportunity' for improved U.S.-Bolivia relations after years of hostility under Morales and Arce.

Despite the political shift, governance may be difficult due to neither candidate winning a congressional majority and the continued influence of former President Evo Morales, who remains a political force despite being barred from office.
Morales faces a human trafficking arrest warrant, which he denies, and has called for a boycott of the vote, raising concerns about potential instability.
Nearly eight million Bolivians are eligible to vote, and voting is mandatory, indicating high civic engagement and potential for a decisive outcome.

namedEntities.name: Jorge "Tuto" Quiroga
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former interim President of Bolivia, 65, running in the presidential run-off election.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents a pro-market, conservative political force and is one of the two main candidates in the run-off election, signaling a shift from socialist rule.

namedEntities.name: Rodrigo Paz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Centrist Senator and economist, 58, running in the presidential run-off election.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents a moderate, market-friendly but socially inclusive alternative to the previous leftist governments and is the other main candidate in the run-off.

namedEntities.name: Movement Towards Socialism (MAS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Long-dominant political party in Bolivia since 2006, led by Evo Morales and later Luis Arce.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The party failed to field a candidate in the run-off, marking the end of its 20-year political hegemony and signaling a major political realignment.

namedEntities.name: Evo Morales
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of Bolivia, who led the country through a period of socialist rule and left-wing policies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His legacy of anti-market, anti-US policies underpins the political shift in the run-off, with his successor Luis Arce and his own supporters still influential.

namedEntities.name: Luis Arce
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Outgoing President of Bolivia, successor to Evo Morales, who maintained socialist policies and ruled during the first round of voting.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His leadership contributed to the political crisis that led to the run-off, and his successor in office (the winner) will face the task of reforming Bolivia’s economy.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Foreign power with which Bolivia has had tense relations under socialist governments.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The election is seen as a turning point in U.S.-Bolivia relations, with both candidates seeking stronger ties, indicating a geopolitical shift.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US Secretary of State, who commented on the election as a transformative opportunity for U.S.-Bolivia relations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His statement underscores the international significance of the election and the desire for a new foreign policy alignment with the US.

namedEntities.name: Felicidad Flores
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: 67-year-old street vendor in La Paz, representing public sentiment.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her perspective illustrates the public's economic hardship and hope for stability, reflecting the lived experience of Bolivians in crisis.

namedEntities.name: Javier Quispe
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: 40-year-old driver in a fuel queue in La Paz, representing public sentiment.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His statement reflects widespread public frustration and pessimism about economic conditions and future prospects.

namedEntities.name: Glaeldys Gonzalez Calanche
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Analyst for the International Crisis Group.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She frames the election as a political turning point, emphasizing the broader shift in Bolivia’s direction.

namedEntities.name: Daniela Osorio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Analyst from the German Institute for Global and Area Studies.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She warns of potential social unrest if reform fails to serve the most vulnerable, highlighting risks of post-election instability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Bolivians are voting in a presidential run-off election that ends nearly two decades of socialist rule under the Movement Towards Socialism (MAS) party. The vote pits conservative former interim President Jorge 'Tuto' Quiroga against centrist economist Rodrigo Paz, both of whom promise economic reforms to address the nation’s severe crisis—marked by inflation over 20%, fuel shortages, and public financial strain. The election signals a shift toward market-oriented policies and improved relations with the United States, despite challenges like neither candidate winning a congressional majority and the continued influence of former President Evo Morales, who faces legal issues and has called for a boycott. Analysts warn that without meaningful reforms, social unrest may follow. With nearly eight million eligible voters and mandatory participation, the outcome could define Bolivia’s future political and economic trajectory.
title: Polls open in crisis-hit Bolivia run-off presidential election
